header.title: Qabalah: The Mystical Heritage of the Children of Abraham

central_thesis: The book argues for a universal mystical spirituality, the 'Mystical Qabalah,' that originated with Abraham and underlies the Abrahamic traditions (Hebrew, Jewish, Christian, Islamic) as well as North Indian Tantra. It distinguishes this experiential path from Rabbinical Judaism and Hermetic/Practical Kabbalah, emphasizing direct consciousness expansion through specific meditative practices centered on the Tree of Life and Divine Names, rather than dogmatic adherence or pursuit of magical power.

structure_content.summary: The author shares his personal journey of seeking the spiritual roots of Judaism beyond Rabbinical interpretations, leading him to the 'Work of the Chariot Trust' and the study of the Sefer Yetzirah and ancient alphabets. He highlights the universal, experiential nature of the Mystical Qabalah as taught by his mentor.

This section introduces the 'Work of the Chariot Trust' and its role in publishing translations of primary Qabalistic texts. It outlines the book's structure, which covers the historical development of the Mystical Qabalah, its primary sources, core teachings, various Tree of Life diagrams, meditation practices, and a glossary of terms.

Examines the historical and philosophical distinctions between the universal Mystical Qabalah, Rabbinical Jewish Kabbalah, Practical/Hermetic Kabbalah, Mystical Christianity, Sufism, and North Indian Tantra. It contextualizes Abraham's monotheistic tradition and suggests connections between ancient Hebrew practices and Eastern mysticism, concluding with a comparison of qabalistic cosmology to modern scientific theories.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: Sources of the Mystical Qabalah
structure_content.summary: Describes the primary textual sources of the Mystical Qabalah of the children of Abraham, including the Sefer HaTorah, Sefer HaShmoth, Sefer Yetzirah, Sefer HaZohar (and its core texts: Sifra Detzniyutha, Idra Rabba Qadusha, Idra Zuta Qadusha), Merkabah literature (Seferim HaChanokh, Sh'ir Qoma), the Qur'an, Peshitta (Gospels), and the Etz HaChayyim. It highlights the Work of the Chariot Trust's unique translations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 3: Core Teachings of the Mystical Qabalah
structure_content.summary: Introduces the foundational concepts of the Ayn (Mysterious Unknown), Vast Face (inactive, impersonal aspect of the Divine), and Small Face (active, personal aspect, Creator/Sustainer/Destroyer). It details the structure and composition of the qabalistic Tree of Life, including its roots, columns, Sefiroth, letter-gates, the four qabalistic worlds (Atziluth, B'riyah, Yetzirah, Asiyah), the qlifoth (shells of embodied existence), and the 'Fall of Adam.' The chapter also discusses the significance of the Divine Name YHVH and the nature of messianic appearance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 4: Trees of Life from the Sefer HaShmoth and the Sefer Yetzirah
structure_content.summary: Presents a variety of Tree of Life forms from the Sefer HaShmoth and Sefer Yetzirah, categorized as 'Angelic Tree Language.' It describes different 'Working Trees' (e.g., Way of Angels of Elohim/Destruction, Way of the Saint/Wizard, Way of YHVH Elohenu, Way of Messiah, Way of the Treasuries of Elohim) and 'Perfect Trees,' detailing their paths and objectives. Special attention is given to the Sefer Yetzirah's descriptions of the twenty-two Hebrew letters as the foundation of creation and their correlations to the physical world.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 5: Trees of Life from Other Primary Qabalistic Sources and Other Mystical Traditions
structure_content.summary: Expands on Tree of Life diagrams from other primary sources like Ezekiel and Isaiah (Merkabah Tree) and the Zohar (Zoharic Rabbi Tree). It draws comparative analogies to non-Abrahamic mystical traditions, including the Tantric Chakra system and the Taoist I Ching's Trigram sequences, highlighting shared universal principles in their maps of consciousness and spiritual ascent.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 6: Meditation and the Mystical Qabalah: Foundation
structure_content.summary: Lays the theoretical and practical foundation for qabalistic meditation. It outlines two main yogic approaches: Vast Face Yoga (impersonal, non-dualistic, discrimination-focused) and Small Face Yoga (personal, devotional, mantra-focused). The chapter incorporates modern analogies from neurology and cybernetics (e.g., 'Holodeck' for manifestation, brain as a computer) to explain mystical concepts. It also details the symbolic generation of the Torah in the Four Worlds and the process of ascending the Tree via the 'Path of YHVH Elohenu.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 7: Meditation Practices of the Mystical Qabalah
structure_content.summary: Provides detailed, practical instructions for engaging in qabalistic meditation. It covers preparing external and internal environments, simple and elaborate routines for Small Face and Vast Face practices, specific visualizations, breathing exercises, mantra repetition, devotional singing, walking meditation, and selfless service. The emphasis is on sincerity, purity of intention, renunciation, surrender, and discrimination for spiritual awakening.

structure_content.chapter_title: Epilogue: Uncovering What You Already Know
structure_content.summary: Reflects on the impermanence of existence, the role of the Chosen Ideal as the true guru, and the importance of inner work. It encourages a universalistic approach to spiritual practice, warning against dogmatism and advocating for 'Hebrew Renewal' as a return to the original, non-rabbinical practices of the desert Hebrews.

key_concepts.definition: Hebrew for 'Nothing'; the deepest of the three negatively-existent roots of the Tree of Life, representing the Mysterious Unknown, absolute Being devoid of attributes. It is the undifferentiated Ground of Pure Being.
Hebrew for 'Without End' or 'Endless'; the second of the three negatively-existent roots of the Tree of Life, describing the infinite aspect of the Divine.
Hebrew for 'Endless Light' or 'Light of the Endless'; the third of the three negatively-existent roots of the Tree of Life, representing the luminous, unmanifest supernal light.

The inactive, impersonal aspect of the Mysterious Unknown (Ayn), denoting a station of infinite consciousness devoid of differentiation and manifest activity. It is associated with the Sefirah Crown/Above.

key_concepts.term: Small Face (Ze'ir Anafin, Alef of Unity)
key_concepts.definition: The active, personal aspect of the Divine, endowed with all possible attributes; the Creator, Sustainer, and Destroyer of the universe. It encompasses all differentiated, manifest activity and is associated with the letter Alef (a).

A universal map of consciousness representing the physio-spiritual entirety of both the individual soul (Microcosm) and the Divine Soul (Macrocosm). It comprises ten Sefiroth connected by twenty-two letter-gates, rooted in the negatively-existent substratum and extending through four qabalistic worlds.

Hebrew for 'Spheres'; the ten stations or centers of consciousness on the Tree of Life, which emanate from the Divine and form the infrastructure of existence. They are often described in pairs of opposites.

Hebrew for 'Shells'; embodied existence, viewed as layers of consciousness differing in size, density, and vibrational rate, correlating with the four qabalistic worlds. Purification of qlifoth is essential for spiritual ascent.

Four planes of existence in Qabalah: Atziluth (Emanation, Supernal World), B'riyah (Creation, formless vibrational signatures), Yetzirah (Formation, astral world of divine archetypes), and Asiyah (Activity, physical material world).

The Tetragrammaton; the principal Name of Small Face in the Mystical Qabalah, also called 'Shem HaMeforesh' or 'Brilliant Name of Fire.' It represents the active (sexual) tantric union of masculine (yang) and feminine (yin) aspects of Vast and Small Face in the Upper and Lower Worlds.

Hebrew for 'Contraction'; a central concept in Lurianic cosmology describing the envacuous circular area from which the Light of the Endless withdraws, allowing the Tree of Life and the Small Face universe to emanate and manifest. Visualized as a black circular background in meditation.

Hebrew for 'Chariot' or 'Throne of Glory'; an allusion to the Tree of Life, particularly the four central Sefiroth of the three-dimensional Tree of Perfection, which are the dwelling place of the Yosher form of YHVH.

An array of Fallen and Perfect Trees of Life sourced in the Sefer HaShmoth, representing different paths of ascension for various practitioners (magicians, saints, yogis) through the Sefirothic patterns. Angels are said to see humans as 'walking Trees.'

Specific forms of the Tree of Life representing paths of spiritual ascent, infused with Divine Names, mantra, or invocations to direct consciousness changes. They reflect different types of spiritual work and often involve the 'Fall of Adam' where Knowledge/First is invisible and Kingdom is at the base.

Forms of the Tree of Life that reflect enlightened yogis, transcendent devotees, saints, and Messiahs, where the Sefirah Knowledge/First is visible and there is no Sefirah at the anal center (Kingdom). They represent a state where the illusion of the Fall into dualistic consciousness no longer exists.
Hebrew for 'Fate'; the law of cause and effect, synonymous with the Sanskrit term 'karma.' It governs the conditional experiences and limitations in the manifest universe.

Hebrew for 'Remembrance'; the qabalistic practice of repeating Divine Names or mantras, equivalent to Arabic 'dikhr' and Sanskrit 'japa' or 'namasmarana.' It purifies desires and cultivates love, renunciation, and concentration.

Sanskrit term for ecstatic absorption in God-without-Qualities; the complete extinction of individuated consciousness in union with the Mysterious Unknown (Ayn), where the sense of a separate self dissolves completely.

Hebrew for 'Divine Presence' or 'Neighborhood'; a central Name for the feminine aspect of the Divine, the energy of consciousness of YHVH. It is often correlated with Kundalini in Tantra and Sakinat in Sufism, said to be in exile in the Lower Worlds.
Hebrew for 'Upright'; a vertical, highly anthropomorphic version of the Name YHVH, representing the 'Divine Body' or 'Celestial Man.' It is used in visualizations for meditation.

practical_system.description: The practical system of the Mystical Qabalah, as presented, centers on the 'ascension of the Central Column of the Tree of Life' to achieve union with the consciousness of Small Face and Vast Face. It emphasizes personalized, unforced yogic practices rather than rigid rituals. The core elements include root mantra repetition (zakhor), combined with specific visualizations (yantra), breathing exercises, and cultivating internal states of unconditional love, renunciation, and discrimination. The goal is to purify the 'shells' (qlifoth) of embodied existence and expand consciousness, ultimately leading to the realization of the 'Mysterious Unknown' (Ayn) at the roots of the Tree.
tools: Dedicated Shrine/Meditation Space: A quiet, peaceful area, ideally a separate room, where spiritual activities, thoughts, and speech are maintained. Includes a personal altar for offerings and an image of the Divine Name.

Image of YHVH: Visual representation of the Hebrew Name (Sinatic or Ezra Hebrew, horizontal or Yosher form) as 'dancing letters of fire' on a circular black (Tzimtzum) and light blue (Endless Light) background.
Comfortable Seating: Pillow, zafu, or chair to maintain an 'upright but comfortable' posture for extended meditation.
Prayer Beads: Optional tool for tracking mantra repetitions.
Prayer Shawl (Tallit Gadol): Optional, worn during meditation to enhance focus and reverence.
Sacred Texts: Primary sources like Sefer HaShmoth, Sefer Yetzirah, Torah, Zohar, Qur'an, Peshitta, and Books of Enoch for study, contemplation, and sourcing mantras.
Candles and Incense: For ritual offerings and creating a sacred atmosphere.
Stone Lingam: An optional tool, particularly for Vast Face practices, symbolizing the potency of Vast Face, over which milk or oil may be poured.
rituals: Breathing practices: Silently intoning 'Yah Hu' coordinated with breath to calm the mind, inhaling 'yah' to the forehead center and exhaling 'hoo' to the heart center to fan the flames of YHVH. This is the healthiest way to breathe and helps sustain extended meditation.

Prostration: An act of reverence and humility, placing the forehead to the Earth to symbolize the extinction of individual consciousness and rising back up to symbolize the manifestation of the Small Face universe. It's a key practice for purifying the ego and cultivating remembrance of the Divine.

Lighting Candles & Incense: Performed with specific blessings (e.g., Sabbath blessing for candles) and intentions, symbolizing light and offering. Incense is used to 'seal the six directions' with permutations of the Name YHV, creating a sacred energetic boundary.

Mantra Repetition (Zakhor/Dikhr/Japa): Silent or audible repetition of root mantras, particularly 'Ani Yod Heh Vav Heh' and 'Shem Ayn,' or 'La Illaha Il Allah' for Sufis. This creates sympathetic vibrations, purifies desires, intensifies love, and cultivates one-pointed concentration.

Visualizations (Yantra): Imagining the Hebrew letters of YHVH (Sinatic or Ezra Hebrew, horizontal or Yosher form) as 'dancing letters of fire' against a black circular background (Tzimtzum) surrounded by a light blue background (Endless Light). Other visualizations include the Shekhinah, Celestial Messiah forms, or the Leviathan.
Devotional Singing/Chanting: Engaging in sacred songs and chants (e.g., Gregorian chants, Hawaiian hulas, Sufi dikhrs) with heart-felt intention to uplift the soul and bring 'Heaven to Earth.'

Walking Meditation: Coordinating mantra repetition with steps while visualizing the Chosen Ideal in every living being or seeing all as living Yoshers/Trees of Life. Can involve contemplating the 'Vast Face Ocean of Endless Light' near bodies of water.

Selfless Service (Mitzvah/Seva/Dana): Performing good deeds and acts of service with conscious awareness of the Divine in those being served, offering the fruits of action to the Lord as a form of 'living zakhor.' This purifies the ego and reminds one of the impermanence of embodied life.

relevant_quotes.text: But, as my heart opened and mind developed, I could not shake a feeling from deep within myself that Rabbinical Judaism had somehow become disconnected from its spiritual taproot. Something essential was missing.
The Mystical Qabalah is a living tradition, dependent upon 'Trees of Perfection' to retransmit its essence and water its roots.

In the Qabalah, the Lord hvhy is the immense I-ness that knows Itself as Pure Being in the unmanifest supernal realm, and pervades everything from Elohim down to the lowest creature in the lower worlds of manifestation.

The Mystical Qabalah summarily involves the ascension of the Central Column of the Tree of Life to progressively unite with the consciousness of Small and Vast Face, and to pierce the profound spiritual mysteries alluded to in the Torah and other primary sources.

The Qabalah is traditionally traced back to Adam and Eve. It has been maintained in its purest forms by unbroken lineages of known and mostly unknown masters, saints, and prophets over thousands of years.

The Tree of Life objectively represents the physio-spiritual entirety of both the individual soul, or Microcosm 'created in the image of Elohim,' and the Divine Soul, or Macrocosm as the 'Body of Celestial Man (Adam Kadmon, ]vmdk ,da).'
The mantra 'Ani Yod Heh Vav Heh' is found in numerous places in the Torah and it is especially recommended for its simplicity and proven effectiveness.
When you awake in your Geviyah, it is best to commence the same meditation practice of repetition of root mantra and visualization that you do in your waking state.
As a Mystical Qabalist, your beloved Lord hvhy is your guide, your 'guru.' He/She will unfold your spiritual path and inspire you to do what is right for you.

The Lord doesn’t need your money to accomplish His/Her works, and doesn’t need temples and rabbis, churches and priests, and mosques and imams to awaken the hearts of the children. The Lord just wants the faithful intention of your mind, and the complete surrender of your heart.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for contemporary esoteric studies as it presents a universalistic and experiential approach to Qabalah, distinct from mainstream Rabbinical or Hermetic traditions. Feldman's work uniquely synthesizes Abrahamic mysticism (Jewish, Christian, Islamic) with Eastern traditions like Tantra and Taoism, fostering a comparative understanding rarely seen. Its focus on primary textual sources and the explicit instructions for practical meditation provide a valuable resource for both academics seeking a broader context for Qabalistic studies and practitioners looking for operative methods beyond traditional dogmas. The integration of modern scientific analogies, though speculative, attempts to bridge ancient wisdom with contemporary thought, enhancing its appeal to a modern esoteric audience.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is esoteric practitioners, particularly those interested in Qabalah, Sufism, Tantra, and comparative mysticism, who seek a direct, experiential path to spiritual awakening. This includes individuals who feel disconnected from orthodox religious structures and are open to a universalistic interpretation of sacred traditions. Scholars of Western Esotericism, Occultism, Religious Studies, and comparative theology will also find value in its technical depth, linguistic analysis, and contextualization of Qabalistic concepts within a broader mystical framework.
